newsitem.title: UK: BA Cargo not hiring capacity despite strike.
newsitem.headline: BA Cargo not hiring capacity despite strike.

text.p: British Airways Plc said it will operate its scheduled freighter flights but will not seek to obtain further cargo space from other airlines, despite the threat of Wednesday's cabin crew strike.

"The decision we have taken is that we will fly our normal cargo schedule but will not seek to obtain further capacity at the present time," BA World Cargo's outsourcing manager Grahem Bunsell told Reuters.
He declined to give a reason for the decision.

Bunsell said that BA's normal cargo schedule comprised weekly Nairobi-London Stansted and Stansted-Johannesburg flights with a DC-8 freighter leased from African International Airways and three-times weekly Stansted-Hong Kong return flights, operated with a 747F wet-leased from U.S. carrier Atlas Air.
Wet-leasing covers the hire of aircraft and crew and usually also includes insurance and maintenance.
"Additionally, we will continue to operate three-times weekly London Heathrow-Tokyo flights jointly with Japan Airlines, using its 747F aircraft," he said.

"We will also continue with our twice-weekly London-Singapore and London-Seoul 747 freighter services operated in conjunction with Singapore Airlines and Korean Air and using those airlines' aircraft," he added.
If the strike goes ahead as planned, BA faces flight cancellations affecting both passengers and cargo.
